questions.question: Which of the following can cause priapism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Spanish fly Explanation: Blister bees/Spanish fly/Cantharis vesicatoria Active principle: Cantharidin Action: Locally irritant and nephrotoxic agent. Absorption: Readily absorbed from all surfaces including skin. Signs and symptoms: Externally: Redness Burning Formation of vesicles On Ingestion: Burning sensation in the mouth, throat and abdomen. Difficulty in swallowing and speech. Dull pain felt in the loins, desire to micturate but urine is scanty and blood stained. Priapism in males and abortion in pregnant females. Patient becomes prostrated with convulsions and coma. Fatal dose and period: 15-30mg of cantharidin or 1.5g of powder 24hrs Treatment: Gastric lavage Demulcents(Not fat) Symptomatic treatment. Post-mortem findings: Externally: Inflammation and vesicles seen in the mouth Internally: Mucus membrane of the oesophagus and stomach is often swollen and engorged. Patches of ulceration and haemorrhages in GIT. Kidneys congested with haemorrhage. Lungs are edematous and congested. Aconitine poisoning (Option A): Caused by consuming plants from the Aconitum genus (like monkshood), leading to severe neurological and cardiovascular symptoms. Strychnine poisoning (Option C): Caused by ingesting strychnine, a potent neurotoxin leading to muscle spasms, seizures, and potentially death due to respiratory failure. Oleander poisoning (Option D): Results from ingesting parts of the oleander plant, which contains cardiac glycosides, leading to nausea, vomiting, and potentially fatal heart issues.

questions.question: A police officer presents an X-ray of a suspect who is believed to be a body packer. Patient acts casual and his vitals are stable The X-ray is as given. What is the most critical initial management step for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Monitor and provide supportive care Explanation: X-ray is suggestive of an asymptomatic Heroin body packer . Most appropriate management would be to monitor and treat the patient symptomatically to excrete the packets. Body packers: Introduction People who illegally carry narcotic drugs (Cocaine/Heroin), either by swallowing or insertion in the vagina/rectum as sealed pellets/packages. Complications GI obstruction/hemorrhage (caused by packets) Packet rupture - Narcotic intoxication Imaging Abdominal X-ray (first-line) Ultrasound or CT Scan (if unclear) Management Asymptomatic Patient: Whole Bowel Irrigation (caution: potential rupture) Alternatives: Allow packages to move into the colon Administer Enemas (Low-Volume Phospho Soda Enemas/ High-Volume Saline Enemas) Avoid Food Ingestion: Until all packages are passed. Encouraging Gastric Emptying :Metoclopramide 10 mg, 8-hourly Symptomatic Patient: Continuous-infusion of Naloxone Whole bowel irrigation. Surgical intervention may be required.

questions.question: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after taking an overdose of morphine. He is unresponsive with a respiratory rate of 6 breaths per minute. Which laboratory finding would you expect in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Hypoxemia Explanation: Morphine is an alkaloid found in opium Morphine causes hypoxemia Findings in Morphine poisoning: Hypoxia and respiratory acidosis is seen due to respiratory depression by acting on mu opiate receptors and in the medulla via mu and delta receptors. Hyperkalaemia occur following an overdose,especially in the presence of rhabdomyolysis and acute renal failure, not hypokalemia. Opioid Receptor Activation: Morphine binds to opioid receptors, particularly the mu-opioid receptors, which can influence various hormonal systems. This activation can lead to altered signaling pathways that may reduce gluconeogenic enzyme activity in the liver and can lead to hypoglycemia. Reference: VV Pillay Modern Medical toxicology, Page 175-177 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK586388/# :~:text=Opium%20is%20a%20highly%20addictive,poppy%20plant%20(Papaver%20somniferum) .

questions.question: A 24 year old female was brought to the emergency department in comatose state and on examination, the vitals were BP:80/40, HR:42/min, RR:8/min, Temperature 36 degree, Reflexes: sluggish, Miosis with conjunctival congestion, spO2:85%. Multiple skin scars were noted on her left forearm.The attenders gave a history of the frequent domestic strife and mood swings following which she would have a long unexplained absence from home. The duty doctor suspected drug abuse and started appropriate management. Which among the following chemical tests can be used for diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Marquis test Explanation: From the above clinical scenario,the triad of coma, pinpoint pupils, and respiratory depression is said to be almost pathognomonic for opiate poisoning . Such cases may be due to therapeutic overdose, accidental overdose (in addicts), or deliberate overdose (suicidal). The following tests are used for the diagnosis for opium poisoning (MDH) M - Marquis test D -Deninges test H- Husemann test Stages of opium poisoning : Stage Symptoms/Characteristics Stage of Excitement Short duration,Euphoria Hallucinations,tachycardia Flushing of face,Conjunctival injection Stage of Stupor Headache,nausea,vomiting Weakness,heaviness in limbs Dizziness, miosis,cyanosis of face and lips Stage of Narcosis/Coma Deep coma (unarousable) Flaccid, relaxed muscles Pale face, Absent reflexes Congested conjunctiva Cold skin with profuse perspiration Pinpoint, non-reactive pupils Hypotension, Weak, feeble pulse, Hypothermia, Bradypnoea Drugs used in Opioid Poisoning: Management of Acute Opioid poisoning: IV Naloxone DOC to prevent relapse: Naltrexone (oral) DOC for Opioid substitution therapy: Buprenorphine > Methadone Marsh test (Option B): Used for the detection of Arsenic McNally's test (Option C): Used for the detection of Salicylates Gutzeit test (Option D): Used for the detection of Strychnine Reference: VV pillay Modern Medical toxicology, Page 175-177 Gautam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Pages 513,538,539.

questions.question: Patient was brought to ED after being bitten by a snake as shown below. Which of the following steps are part of management in this patient? 1) Immobilize the limb by applying crepe bandages 2) Cauterize the bite wound 3) No test dose to be given before starting ASV 4) Dose of ASV should be halved in children 5) ASV given until clotting time becomes normal
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 3,5 Explanation: Snake shown in the image is Russel’s viper , which is hemotoxic. Application of crepe bandage or cauterization of wound is not indicated for Viper bite. Treatment of snake bite: First Aid: ‘ CARRY NO RIGHT ’ CARRY Do not allow the victim to walk on their own, must be carried (in any form) to the hospital as soon as possible. NO No Suction No Cautery No Ligature No Tourniquet RIGHT R: Reassure the patient I: Immobilize the limb: by application of crepe bandages (Sutherland wraps) GH: Get to the Hospital immediately T: Tell history/symptoms Pressure bandage Used for immobilization of the limb by application of crepe bandage - known as Sutherland wraps . Contraindicated in viper bites. Ideal pressure: 50-70 mm Hg. ASV Mainstay of treatment. Used only when signs of systemic poisoning are present Polyvalent

questions.question: Which of the following snakes is known for its myotoxic venom?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sea snake Explanation: Sea snake venom is highly myotoxic, causing significant muscle damage, which can lead to rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury. Clinical features of myotoxic snake venom: Common in Sea Snakes: Myotoxic venoms are characteristic of particularly sea snakes. Muscle necrosis (First finding): Myotoxic venoms cause direct damage to muscle fibers (skeletal muscle), leading to muscle cell death (necrosis). Rhabdomyolysis : Breakdown of muscle tissue results in the release of muscle contents, such as myoglobin, into the bloodstream. Elevated Creatine Kinase (CK): A marker of muscle damage, CK levels are significantly elevated in cases of myotoxic envenomation. Myoglobinuria : The release of myoglobin can overwhelm the kidneys, leading to myoglobin in urine, which can cause acute kidney injury. Muscle Weakness : Progressive muscle pain and weakness are common symptoms due to muscle breakdown. Tests for neurotoxic and vasculotoxic snake bite Neurotoxic Test Vasculotoxic Test Single Breath Count Test Count numbers in a single breath. Repeat the counting test every 15 minutes. If it decreases, it indicates ongoing respiratory failure. Whole Blood Clotting Test (WBCT) Put whole blood in a clean and dry test tube. Wait for 20 minutes and analyse the blood in the test tube. After 20 minutes if blood clots: No snake bite or not vasculotoxic venom. After 20 minutes if blood does not clot: Suggests Viper snake poisoning. King cobra (Option A): Primarily neurotoxic. Russell’s Viper (Option C): Primarily vasculotoxic. Banded krait (Option D): Primarily neurotoxic.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key difference between neurotoxic and vasculotoxic snake venoms? respiratory paralysis.

options.A: Neurotoxic venom local reaction is extensive and vasculotoxic venom local reaction is minimal
options.B: Tongue paralysis is seen in vasculotoxic snakes.
options.C: Neurotoxic venom leads to severe swelling at the bite site, while vasculotoxic venom causes
options.D: Neurotoxic venom causes wet gangrene , while vasculotoxic venom causes dry gangrene.

questions.explanation: gangrene. Correct Answer: D) Neurotoxic venom causes wet gangrene , while vasculotoxic venom causes dry gangrene. Explanation: Ophitoxaemia characterises the clinical spectrum of snakebite envenomation. Clinical features Neurotoxic snakes (Elapidae) Vasculotoxic (Viper) Causes muscular, weakness of legs and paralysis of muscles of face, throat and respiration. Causes enzymatic destruction of cell walls and coagulation disorders causing hemolysis. Ptosis: B/L drooping of eyelid -M/C DIC - Disseminated Intravascular Coagulopathy causing renal failure. Local reaction: Minimal ( Option A ) Local reaction: Extensive Tongue paralysis seen (Option B) Tongue not affected Descending paralysis, Respiratory paralysis with dysphagia, dysphonia and dysarthria. (Option C) Circulatory failure Wet gangrene, early onset (Option D) Dry gangrene, late onset Pulse: Initially normal, then irregular. Pulse: weak and irregular Coagulation not affected Coagulation with hemorrhagic manifestations Normal pupils Pupils dilated Hypersalivation Normal salivation Staggering gait Not affected specifically Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd Edition, Pages 527, 528.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a physical feature of a poisonous snake?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Small belly scales Explanation: Small belly scales are found in non-poisonous snakes Poisonous and non-poisonous snakes Poisonous snakes Non-poisonous snakes Head scales: Small, large scales seen with heat sensing pit antero-inferior to the eye. Head scales: Large with certain exceptions. Belly scales: Large and cover the entire breadth of belly. Belly scales: Small like those on the back and do not cover the entire breadth. Fangs: Long and canalized like a hypodermic needle. Fangs: Short and solid. Single row of scales. Double rows of scales. Tail compressed Tail not markedly compressed. Bite marks: Two fang marks, with or without small marks of other teeth. Bite marks: Number of small teeth marks in row. Features of common poisonous snakes (Identification and differences) and fatal doses Snakes Features and fatal doses Common cobra Head and neck: Hood present with spectacle marks Belly: Smooth scales Back: Spectacled white or yellow Colour: Brown/black/green Neurotoxic : Elapids Fatal dose(Dried form)= 15mg King cobra Head and neck: Hood present without spectacle marks Belly: Scales look shiny but dry to touch. Back: Yellow or black bands with broad chevron like markings. Colour: Yellow/black/green with white cross bands. Neurotoxic : Elapids Fatal dose(Dried form)= 12mg Common krait Head and neck: Covered with large shields. Belly: Creamy white Back: Single/double white bands with central row of hexagonal scales. Colour: Steel blue/black. Neurotoxic : Elapids Fatal dose(Dried form)= 2-5-6mg Banded krait Head and neck: Covered with large shields. Belly: Triangular in cross section. Back: Alternate black and yellowish bands. Colour: Steel blue/black. Neurotoxic : Elapids Fatal dose(Dried form)= 10 mg Russell’s viper Head and neck: Flat triangular with distinct ‘V’ mark and small scales. Belly: White with broad plates. Back: Three rows of diamond shaped black spots. Colour: Brown/buff Vasculotoxic Fatal dose(Dried form)= 40 mg

questions.question: What is the treatment of choice for the sting of the organism given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Prazosin Explanation: The image is of Indian red scorpion The treatment of choice for Indian red scorpion sting (Mesobuthus tamulus) is prazosin. Scorpion sting venom: Physical properties: Venom is clear, colorless, proteinous toxalbumin, having haemolytic and neurotoxic effects. Action: Venom is a potent autonomic stimulator, resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. Signs and symptoms: Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles developed within hours. Local : Swelling, prominent, radiating pain, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (Tap test) Systemic effects: Restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements, profuse sweating, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, respiratory depression and pulmonary edema. Complications : Tachycardia,hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis and acidosis. Treatment: Limb is mobilised and pressure bandage is applied proximal to the site of sting. The site may be incised and washed with ammonia or borax. Prazosin therapy :Treatment of choice (1mg for adults, 500 I g for children) is given orally and then after every 3 hours till extremities are warm, dry, and peripheral veins are visible. Scorpion antivenom (SAV) Specific antidote for scorpion venom. Calcium gluconate 10 ml of 10% solution slow IV given for pain, cramps and edema. Barbiturates given to sedate and control convulsion. Atropine to prevent pulmonary edema. Post-mortem findings: Affected site is swollen Stinger area showing ecchymosis Pulmonary edema Myocardial infarction

questions.question: What is the mechanism of action of the poison found in these seeds (image)?

options.A: Stimulation of anterior horn cells of spinal cord
options.B: Inhibition of anterior horn cells of spinal cord
options.C: Stimulation of posterior horn of spinal cord
options.D: Inhibition of posterior horn of spinal cord

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Stimulation of anterior horn cells of spinal cord Explanation: The given seeds are that of Strychnos nux-vomica and the poison is Strychnine which acts by stimulating all parts of the central nervous system, especially the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord Strychnine: Source Seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica and other species of Strychnos plants found in India. Mechanism of action Stimulates all parts of the central nervous system, especially the anterior horn cells. Greatly increases reflex excitability by removing normal inhibition of motor cell stimulation, causing widespread uncontrolled motor activity of the spinal cord (Option A) Slight stimuli like noise, light, or a breeze can cause violent generalized muscle spasms Differentiating Points Strychnine Poisoning Tetanus 1. History History of poisoning History of injury 2. Onset Sudden onset Gradual onset 3. Convulsions/Spasms Generalized convulsions Lockjaw (trismus) 4. Chest Movement Chest fixed during convulsions Not typically fixed 5. Relaxation Between Spasms Complete relaxation between seizures Relaxation between spasms is never complete 6. Duration Until Fatality Ends fatally within a few hours Death is rare within a few hours 7. Chemical Evidence Chemical analysis reveals the poison No specific chemical detection

questions.question: A forensic pathologist is conducting an autopsy on a 38-year-old male who died after an accidental exposure to hydrofluoric acid (HF) at an industrial plant. Which of the following postmortem findings is most characteristic of HF poisoning?

options.C: Severe hypocalcemia and calcium deposits in tissues

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Severe hypocalcemia and calcium deposits in tissues Explanation: Hydrofluoric acid binds with calcium in the body, causing hypocalcemia and leading to the precipitation of calcium salts in tissues. This can be a characteristic finding in both clinical and postmortem evaluations of HF poisoning cases. Hydrofluoric Acid (HF) Chemical Properties Aqueous solution of hydrogen fluoride (HF) in concentrations from 0.5% (domestic) to 100% (industrial). Potent dehydrating agent; causes chemical burns. Sources and Uses Found in rust removers, detergents, cleaning agents. Used in glass etching, metal processing, fluorine compound production. Mechanism of Toxicity Corrosive: Hydrogen ions cause immediate tissue damage by coagulative necrosis. Fluoride ion toxicity: Fluoride ions penetrate tissues, leading to liquefactive necrosis and systemic toxicity. Routes of Exposure Dermal contact: Common, causes severe burns. Inhalation: Leads to respiratory distress. Ingestion: Causes gastrointestinal burns. Symptoms Dermal burns: Severe pain, redness, necrosis (may be delayed). Ocular injury: Conjunctivitis, corneal erosion, possible vision loss. Respiratory issues: Coughing, dyspnea, pulmonary edema (from inhalation). Gastrointestinal distress: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain (from ingestion). Neuromuscular: Confusion, seizures due to electrolyte imbalances (hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia). Autopsy Findings Severe burns in esophageal and gastric mucosa. Hyperemic lesions in the renal tubular system. Necrotic lesions in cardiac muscle. Management Promptly rinse the area with water or saline for at least 30 minutes. Apply 2.5% calcium gluconate gel every 10-15 minutes until pain subsides. Severe cases may require intravenous calcium gluconate, airway support, and monitoring of electrolytes in an ICU setting. Cherry-red discoloration of the blood (Option A): This is typically associated with carbon monoxide poisoning, not HF poisoning. Black tarry stool (melena) (Option B) : Melena is associated with upper gastrointestinal bleeding, which is unrelated to HF poisoning. Widespread gastric mucosal erosion (Option D): This finding is more typical of ingestion of strong acids or corrosives but is not specific to HF poisoning. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441829/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4098557/ N S Narayana Reddy and OP Murty, The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & toxicology, 35th Edition, Page 406

questions.question: A 32-year-old man is found unconscious with a strong odor of antiseptic on his breath. He is rushed to the emergency department where he develops hypotension and renal failure. On examination, his angle of mouth is stained gray, and he has burns on his esophagus. The patient had a history of greenish discoloration of urine. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Carbolic acid poisoning Explanation : Carbolic acid (phenol) poisoning presents with Gray/brown corrosions on mouth, esophageal burns, a strong antiseptic odor, CNS depression, hypotension and renal failure due to its toxic effects on the central nervous system, cardiovascular system and kidneys. Phenol Poisoning (Carbolism) Physical Properties Colorless, crystalline, turns pink on air exposure; slightly acidic, forms phenolate ion (C6H5O I ). Uses Antiseptic/disinfectant; Lysol (50% cresol), Dettol (chlorinated phenol with turpineol). Fatal Dose 1-2 g phenol or 25-50 ml of household phenol. Fatal Period 3-4 hours. Tissue Discoloration Can lead to ochronosis (bluish-black discoloration in tissues like ears and sclera). Signs and symptoms Local Effects: Tingling → numbness → coagulation necrosis → painless white eschar, which turns brown and sloughs off. Gastrointestinal: Initial burning/tingling, later anesthesia; diarrhea and abdominal pain, vomiting rare. Respiratory: Phenol odor on breath, laryngeal/pulmonary edema, stertorous breathing, cyanosis. Metabolized by kidneys into hydroquinone/pyrocatechol; causes carboluria ( dark green urine ). Cardiovascular (CVS): Rapid, feeble, irregular pulse; cold, clammy skin; collapse, unconsciousness, coma. Muscular: Muscle spasms, convulsions CNS: Headache, giddiness, tinnitus, contracted pupils. Renal: Dark smoky green color of urine. Postmortem Findings External: Gray/brown corrosions on mouth, body, hands; phenolic odor, delayed putrefaction. Internal: Corroded GIT mucosa, leathery stomach, pulmonary edema, hemorrhagic nephritis. Medico-legal Aspects Used in suicides, accidental poisoning, rare for homicides (strong odor/taste), abortifacient. Oxalic acid poisoning (Option A) : Oxalic acid causes renal damage, resulting in swollen, congested kidneys with tubular necrosis, along with gelatinous brown content in the stomach. It lacks the characteristic antiseptic odor associated with carbolic acid. Sulfuric acid poisoning (Option B): Produces black burns, but there is no antiseptic odor, and sulfuric acid is more likely to cause severe external chemical burns rather than the systemic effects seen here. Nitric acid poisoning (Option D): Causes yellow burns and severe systemic toxicity, but lacks the distinctive odor. Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd Edition, Page 486, 487 Parikh's Textbook of Medical Jurisprudence, Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 8th Edition, Page 557

questions.question: A forensic pathologist is performing autopsies on two individuals who died from chemical poisoning. One case involves nitric acid and the other oxalic acid. Which of the following postmortem findings is most consistent with oxalic acid poisoning rather than nitric acid poisoning?

options.A: Yellow discoloration of the skin with congestion of the larynx and trachea
options.C: Soft, friable stomach wall with ulceration
options.D: Gelatinous brown stomach content with swollen, congested kidneys showing necrosis

questions.explanation: necrosis Correct Answer: D) Gelatinous brown stomach content with swollen, congested kidneys showing necrosis Explanation : Oxalic acid causes renal damage, resulting in swollen, congested kidneys with tubular necrosis, along with gelatinous brown content in the stomach. Gastric lavage with calcium lactate is indicated in oxalic acid poisoning. Feature HNO I (Nitric Acid) Oxalic Acid Physical Properties Colorless, pungent, choking, burning taste, fuming Colorless, transparent, prismatic crystals, resembles MgSO I and ZnSO I Fatal Dose 10–15 ml 15–20 g Fatal Period 12–24 hours 1–2 hours (may extend to 2 days–2 weeks with renal failure) Signs and Symptoms Oropharyngeal burns, pain in throat and epigastrium Dysphagia, dyspnea, dysphonia Eructation, vomiting Thirst Fulminating: Immediate symptoms, coffee-ground vomiting, severe thirst, diarrhea, electrolyte imbalance, death within minutes Acute: Tingling, numbness, tetany, convulsions, renal failure Delayed: Nephritis, oxaluria, renal failure Vomitus Acidic, contains altered blood and mucous Coffee-ground vomitus Teeth Yellowish coating, not brittle No specific change Urination & Tenesmus Present Renal failure, scanty urine, oxaluria Abdominal Findings Abdominal distension due to gas Tenderness Stiffness (due to distension) Burning pain, abdominal distension Skin and Mucosa Erosion Yellow discoloration over angles of mouth, lips, fingers No external findings Mucosal bleaching, corrosion in mouth, esophagus, stomach Perforation of Stomach Less common No perforation, gelatinous brown content in stomach (Option D) (Option B ruled out) Postmortem Findings (Option A and D ruled out) Yellow discoloration of skin Congestion of larynx, trachea Soft, friable stomach wall, ulcerated Bleached mucosa (mouth, pharynx, esophagus) Red, velvety or blackish stomach wall Swollen, congested kidneys with necrosis Medico-Legal Aspects Accidental or suicidal , homicide rare Usually accidental (mistaken for MgSO I ) , rare in suicides or homicides, occasionally used as an abortifacient Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd Edition, Page 482, 483, 485, 486

questions.question: A 40 year old man was found unconscious at home, with an open container of unknown acid nearby. He was rushed to the ER but died shortly after arrival. During autopsy, the police surgeon notes several injuries consistent with corrosive ingestion along with chalky white, brittleteeth. Which forensic finding would solidify the above finding in this case?

options.B: Blackish staining and necrosis of the lips and mouth
options.D: Yellowish staining and necrosis of the lips and mouth

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Blackish staining and necrosis of the lips and mouth Explanation : Sulfuric acid is highly corrosive and can cause characteristic blackish burns, particularly on the mucosal surfaces, such as the lips and mouth along with chalky white, brittle teeth. This is a key forensic finding in sulfuric acid ingestion cases. Sulfuric Acid (H I SO I ) Physical Properties: Colorless, odorless, with a burning taste; oily and non-fuming. Fatal Dose: 5–10 ml of concentrated acid. Fatal Period: 12–18 hours post-ingestion. Signs and Symptoms Burning sensation and pain in the throat and epigastric region. Dysphagia, dyspnea, dysphonia Eructation and vomiting: Frequent belching and vomiting. Thirst: Present (worsened vomiting by drinking fluids) Vomitus: Strongly acidic, contains altered blood and mucous shreds. Teeth: Become chalky white and brittle. Constipation: Usually present. Urination: Suppressed. Tenesmus present Nature of stool: Presence of mucus and altered blood. Tenderness over the abdomen Abdominal stiffness due to peritonitis Abdominal distension: Uncommon. Skin and mucous membrane erosion: Especially on the mouth, lips, and fingers; blackening and excoriation occur. Stomach Perforation: Frequently seen. Cause of Death Shock, stomach perforation, peritonitis, laryngeal spasm, and malnutrition from esophageal stricture. Postmortem Findings Erosion of skin and mouth angles, black charring of the stomach, stomach perforation, and swelling in the liver and kidneys. Perforation of stomach Thinning of posterior wall of the stomach Medico-Legal Aspects Often occurs accidentally (mistaken for glycerin) or in suicide cases. Rarely associated with homicide. May be used as an abortifacient or for vitriolage (acid attacks). Bright red lividity (Option A): This is typically associated with carbon monoxide poisoning, not sulfuric acid poisoning. Greenish discoloration of the skin (Option C): This is more typical of certain copper compounds , not sulfuric acid poisoning.. Yellowish staining and necrosis of the lips and mouth (Option D): This is typically associated with nitric acid poisoning.

questions.question: In cases of poisoning by corrosive substances, gastric lavage can be performed in which of the following situations? A) Sulphuric acid poisoning B) Hydrochloric acid poisoning C) Carbolic acid (Phenol) poisoning D) Ammonia poisoning E) Oxalic acid poisoning
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Only C and E Explanation: Gastric lavage can be performed with caution for carbolic acid (Phenol) poisoning using lukewarm water, charcoal, olive oil, or magnesium sulfate. Care is taken to prevent further absorption of the corrosive substance. In oxalic acid poisoning, gastric lavage with calcium lactate (2 tsp/lavage) is done Type of Poison Management Mineral Acids (Sulphuric acid, Nitric acid, Hydrochloric acid) Avoid gastric lavage/emetics. Dilute by giving milk or water. Administer 4 tablespoons of aluminum hydroxide gel. Provide demulcents (olive oil, milk, egg white, starch water, butter). Avoid bicarbonate or neutralizing agents. Prednisolone: 60 mg/day in divided doses. Treat shock with IV fluids, blood products (if bleeding), and antibiotics (if perforation is suspected). Tracheostomy for glottic edema. Nothing by mouth for a week, followed by IV nutrients, gradually reintroducing liquids, soft foods, and regular diet. Morphine for pain relief. Symptomatic treatment. Organic Acids Oxalic Acid Gastric lavage with calcium lactate (2 tsp/lavage). Antidotes: Limewater, calcium lactate, calcium gluconate/chloride (150 mg/kg orally) to form insoluble calcium oxalate for excretion. Calcium gluconate: 10 ml of 10% solution IV frequently. Parathyroid extracts: 100 units IM. Bowel management: Demulcent drinks, enemas, purgatives. Hemodialysis/exchange transfusion if needed. Symptomatic treatment. Carbolic Acid (Phenol) Gastric lavage (done with caution) with lukewarm water, charcoal, olive oil, MgSO4, or Na2SO4. Leave medicinal liquid paraffin or 30 g MgSO4 in the stomach after lavage. Provide demulcents. IV saline with 7 g NaHCO3/l to manage circulatory depression, dilute carbolic acid and promote diuresis. If phenol contacts the skin: Remove contaminated clothing, wash with soap and water, and apply olive oil/methylated spirit. Emetics have a limited role. Alkalis Gastric lavage/emetics contraindicated. Immediately dilute with water. Give demulcents (egg white, milk). Administer O2 inhalation in case of ammonia vapor poisoning Maintain airway, tracheostomy if needed. Administer parenteral analgesics and antibiotics. Steroids contraindicated if esophageal perforation is present. Note: Alkali will cause liquefactive necrosis-more toxic Acid will cause coagulative necrosis Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd Edition, Page 483, 485, 487

questions.question: What is the mechanism of action of the toxin present in this plant?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Causes extrasystoles Explanation: The given plant is Digitalis Purpurea, which In toxic doses, increases cardiac excitability and causes extrasystoles. Digitalis Purpurea (Foxglove): Source Roots, leaves, and seeds contain several glycosides: digitoxin, digitalin, digitalein, and digitonin (most poisonous). Mechanism of action Glycosides act on the heart , improving heart function by prolonging the diastolic period. In toxic doses, they increase excitability and cause extrasystoles. Treatment ECG monitoring. Gastric lavage with tannic acid solution. Activated charcoal. Purgatives if needed. Atropine for bradycardia. Potassium chloride to reduce extrasystoles. Lignocaine, novocaine, or propranolol for cardiac arrhythmias. Trisodium EDTA may help

questions.question: Given is the image of a poisonous plant. Which part of this plant is poisonous?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) All parts Explanation: Given is the image of Cerbera Thevetia (Yellow Oleander, Pila Kaner), all of its parts are poisonous. Yellow Oleander: Source All parts of the plant are poisonous. (Option B) Active Principles Glycosides: Thevetin, thevotoxin, cerberin, peruvoside. Thevetin: A powerful cardiac poison. Thevotoxin: Less toxic than thevetin, similar to digitalis glycosides. Cerberin: Acts like strychnine. Symptoms Local: Sap may cause inflammation. Ingestion: Burning sensation in the mouth, tingling of the tongue, dry throat, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dizziness. Later stages: Dilated pupils, drowsiness, loss of muscular power, rapid/weak/irregular pulse, falling blood pressure, heart block. Death: Due to peripheral circulatory failure. Treatment Gastric lavage and single-dose activated charcoal. IV sodium lactate molar solution and 5% glucose to combat acidosis. Atropine, Adrenaline, and Noradrenaline to counteract heart block and low blood pressure. Digoxin-specific antibody fragments to treat life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias. Symptomatic treatment. Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd Edition, Page 579-580

questions.question: Which of the following statements on aconite is false?

options.A: All parts of the plant are poisonous

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Easily detected postmortem Explanation: Aconite is difficult to detect postmortem Aconite: Species Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox Synonyms Monk’s hood , mitha zaher, bish, wolf’s bane, women’s bane, devil’s helmet, or blue rocket Source All parts of the plant are poisonous (Option A ruled out) Root and root tubers are the most potent (often mistaken for horseradish root) Active Principles Aconitine, pseudo-aconitine, indaconitine, picraconitine, aconine. Mechanism of Action Affects voltage-sensitive sodium channels, stimulates then paralyzes sensory nerves, secretory nerves, CNS, and myocardium. (Option C ruled out) Symptoms (by system) GIT: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, abdominal pain, diarrhea, burning/tingling of mouth, tongue, throat, followed by numbness. CVS: Hypotension, bradycardia , chest pain, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation, slow/feeble pulse. CNS: Vertigo, restlessness, headache, giddiness. MS: Muscle weakness, twitching, spasms. RS: Slow, labored, shallow breathing. Ocular: Alternating pupil dilation/contraction (hippus) , diplopia, impaired vision. Others: Subnormal temperature, cold skin, yellow-green vision, tinnitus, paralysis of facial muscles. Death: Respiratory failure or ventricular fibrillation. Fatal Dose Root: 1-2 g. (Option D ruled out) Treatment No specific antidote. Gastric lavage with tannic acid/activated charcoal. Inotropic therapy for hypotension, atropine for bradycardia. Ventricular arrhythmia treated with amiodarone, flecainide; cardiopulmonary bypass for refractory cases. Medico-legal Aspects Ideal homicidal poison: cheap, easily available, small lethal dose, short fatal period, difficult to detect postmortem. (Option B) Accidental poisoning: mistaken for horseradish

questions.question: Which of the following statements on strychnine poisoning is wrong?

options.C: Strychnine can be detected in putrefied bodies and viscera
options.D: Brain and spinal cord should be preserved for analysis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Rigor mortis sets in late Explanation: In the case of Strychnine poisoning, rigor mortis sets in early Clinical Features Opisthotonos - arched body with only the back of head and heels touching the ground: Emprosthotonos- forward curve Pleurothotonus- sideways curve Risus sardonicus- fixed grin: Treatment - Immediate Care: Place in a dark, quiet room. - Anesthesia: Chloroform or intravenous barbiturate if spasms allow. - Adsorption: Administer animal charcoal to absorb free strychnine, or tannic acid if charcoal is unavailable. - Antidotes: Intravenous barbiturates to stop convulsions. - Muscle relaxants: Mephenesin, intravenous diazepam for anticonvulsant effects. Autopsy Findings - Rigor mortis: Sets in almost immediately (Option A) and passes off early. - Stomach contents: Remains of seeds may be found. - Delayed putrefaction. (Option B ruled out) - Toxicological analysis: Strychnine can be detected in putrefied bodies and viscera (Option C ruled out) ; brain and spinal cord should be preserved for analysis. (Option D ruled out)
